awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Topology-Aware Image Understanding using Deep Variational Objectives
awd_abstract_narration:
Image segmentation, which extracts objects of interest from given images, is a fundamental computer vision task. This project develops novel image segmentation methodology combining classic mathematical foundations and modern deep neural networks. In particular, the developed methodology will achieve high quality in segmenting fine-scale object instances, as well as their topology. Correct segmentation of fine-details and topology such as connectivity between parts is critical for downstream analysis such as reasoning about affordance of objects - what actions can be made on them - and biomedical image analysis. This project not only bridges the gap between principled mathematical theory and the practical deep image segmentation framework, but also trains the next generation of researchers and educators. Through a carefully designed integrated educational and outreach plan, the principal investigators will engage undergraduate students, high school students, women, and other underrepresented students in the research activities.

This project studies deep variational relaxations of segmentation problems, namely, consider the segmentation task as a continuous valued prediction problem and employ variational functionals as training loss functions for deep neural networks. The introduction of deep learning allows highly nonlinear functions to be estimated and greatly improves the capability of variational approaches such as the Mumford-Shah functional and the persistent homology, in segmenting instances with sharp boundaries and with correct topology. Applications on robotic affordance and influence prediction and medical imaging will improve state-of-the-arts in those areas. The resulting techniques and software will be validated on image segmentation, affordance and medical imaging datasets, in order to provide quantitative assessments of the proposed approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Image segmentation, the task to delineate important objects separately and precisely from an image, has been studied by many in the past. However, most existing metrics, as well as losses, focus on getting the object areas mostly correct, with a lack of regard of fine details, such as the exact fitting of the boundaries, as well as the topology (connectivity, holes, voids, etc). Although errors in these details might only occur in a small set of pixels, they may have crucial impacts on the results of the segmentation, and downstream analysis. For example, when segmenting a blood vessel, whether the vessel segment is connected or not can significantly change downstream biological interpretation. Such topological errors of the segmentation are often overlooked because of their relatively small scale in the image. 
This project aims to improve image segmentation in terms of these fine details. It brings together a team of two PIs from computational topology and computer vision. During the project, we have proposed many different tools to direct deep learning algorithms to better focus on the important details in image segmentation, and obtained new results across images, videos, biomedical imaging and robotics.
The most prominent work from this project is a series of tools that were proposed to take topological information into consideration in deep learning models. During the training of these models, mathematical tools such as persistent homology and discrete Morse theory have been adopted so the model learns the correct topology from the training data -- e.g. if the blood vessel is a connected segment in the annotated image, the network should also learn to predict a connected vessel. Through the use of the aforementioned mathematical tools, importance of the different structures are measured and the training algorithms receive those instructions in the form of gradients to adjust their network weights, hence producing a trained network that better preserves those properties. Besides topological properties, the team has also proposed tools inspired from the classical Mumford-Shah theory to improve the adherence to object boundaries during the segmentation, as well as an algorithm that jointly looks at the segmentation of the same object in several consecutive frames in the video to improve the segmentation in a key frame.
These algorithms are applied to various domains where they significantly improve the preservation of topology and boundaries in segmentations. In medical imaging, the PIs applied it to chest radiographs for predicting COVID-19 outcomes, knee radiographs for osteoarthritis, the segmentation of human coronary arteries and organs, neurons, and retinal vessels. In computer vision, it was applied to improve the segmentation of common objects in images and videos. It has also been applied to road segmentation and crack detection in the road. Finally, a robot hand utilized these information to better discover and track novel objects throughout a video that might be revealed after moving away the objects in front of them.
